page.title: 08Culmstock after World War 1
page.content: by Mr. and Mrs.Channon Life in Culmstock just after the lst World War was different from life today in many ways. People mainly travelled by horse and trap and outside the Ilminster Stage a wagonette stopped to take passengers to Wellington,4 miles away,and back. The first cars in the village belonged to Mr. Knowlman and Mr. Collier and there was a motorised van that used to come around selling Brook Bond tea.People didn't leave the village much as there were four general shops, two cobblers,three butchers and a blacksmith in the village. House work was far harder and took much longer in those days.Cutlery would be cleaned with water and a brick while washing the clothes would take all day as they first had to be boiled in a copper.
